div.head: Expositio problematum Aristotelis, Particula XIX: De harmonia
By Pietro d'Abano, edited by Caleb Mutch
div.p: This is a sample of my critical edition of Pietro d'Abano's commentary on book XIX ("Concerning Music") of the pseudo-Aristotelian Problemata. The Problemata was the first Ancient Greek text discussing music in detail to be rediscovered in the High Medieval period, and it contains much information about musical performance practice that would have been unfamiliar to readers at the time, for whom Boethius's speculative approach to music theorizing was authoritative. Consequently, the unfamiliar material was in need of a commentator.

Pietro d'Abano, an Italian polymath who lived about the turn of the fourteenth century, set himself the task of explaining the entirety of the Problemata, a thirty-nine-book tome that seeks to explain much of the natural world. The specific text he commented on was a recently completed Latin translation that followed the usual practice of rendering each Greke word with its closest Latin equivalent, rendering an entirely unidiomatic Latin text. Consequently, Pietro first paraphrases the text into a more Latinate version, and then he explains the issues that arise.

My XML encoding of the text classifies every textual variant, allowing for readers to filter out types of variation (differences in spelling, word ordering, and so forth) as they like. Variants may be viewed by mousing-over the dialog boxes beside each paragraph of the text, or viewed in the traditional Apparatus Criticus format below. Clicking on the dialog boxes allows viewers to substitute their chosen variants into the main text. The abbreviations following each reading indicate which manuscript or family of manuscripts contains that reading; an account of all the manuscripts (including hyperlinks to online versions, where available) may be found at the end of the page.

I have also enabled readers to filter out readings found only in Jean de Jandun's redaction of the text. Shortly after Pietro finished his commentary, Jean (a leading scholar at the University of Paris) produced a revision of Pietro's work, and a third of the surviving manuscripts descend from Jean's redaction. As a result, they do not help to establish Pietro's original text, but they provide an informative witness to the text's reception at a major source of learning. My thanks to the Digital Latin Library, from whom I have adapted this "reading room" viewer for XML-based critical editions.
